User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the Re-Source application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user entity.

isBlocked.description: Indicates if the user is blocked from using the application.

userId.description: Reference to the User who created the listing. (Relationship: User 1:N Listing)

description.description: Detailed description of the resource being listed.

category.description: Category of the resource (e.g., textbook, notes).

semester.description: Semester for which the resource is relevant.

imageUrl.description: URL of the image associated with the listing.

ChatMessage.title: ChatMessage
ChatMessage.description: Represents a message exchanged between users in the chat feature.

id.description: Unique identifier for the chat message.

senderId.description: Reference to the User who sent the message. (Relationship: User 1:N ChatMessage (Sender))

receiverId.description: Reference to the User who received the message. (Relationship: User 1:N ChatMessage (Receiver))

timestamp.description: Timestamp indicating when the message was sent.

Wishlist.title: Wishlist
Wishlist.description: Represents a user's wishlist, containing references to saved listings.

userId.description: Reference to the User who owns the wishlist. (Relationship: User 1:N Wishlist)

listingIds.description: References to Listings saved in the wishlist. (Relationship: Listing N:N Wishlist)

Recommendation.title: Recommendation
Recommendation.description: Represents a personalized resource recommendation for a user.

userId.description: Reference to the User for whom the recommendation is generated. (Relationship: User 1:N Recommendation)

listingId.description: Reference to the Listing being recommended. (Relationship: Listing 1:N Recommendation)

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to provide a secure, scalable, and easily maintainable data model for the Re-Source application, adhering to the principles of Authorization Independence, Clarity of Intent, DBAC (Database-Based Access Control), and QAPs (Rules are not Filters).  

Authorization Independence is achieved through denormalization. Specifically, for Listings, the `userId` is stored directly within each listing document, which is essential for ownership-based access control without requiring `get()` calls in security rules. For collaborative data (which doesn't exist in the current model, but anticipating future expansion) we would typically denormalize membership maps.

Structural Segregation is used by placing different data types into separate collections (e.g., `users`, `listings`, `chat_messages`), ensuring that each collection has a homogeneous security posture.  Path-Based ownership (`/users/{userId}/wishlists/{wishlistId}`) is utilized for entities representing a User 1:N Entity relationship, making security rules simple and efficient.  This applies to wishlists.

Access Modeling is standardized: Private data related to users is stored under their respective user ID, while shared data (currently none, but would apply to collaborative listings) could use membership maps if needed.  

QAPs (Rules are not Filters) are supported via structural segregation.  Secure list operations are enabled by ensuring that security rules can efficiently determine access based on the document path and the current user's authentication state, without needing to filter data based on document content.

For invariants: Ownership is enforced via path-based structures, which provides secure association between entities, such as users and their listings.
